newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: POLICE INVESTIGATING SENATOR'S EXPENSES
The Australian Federal Police has confirmed its investigating allegations relating to the use by Liberal Senator Bob Woods of parliamentary expenses.
Senator Woods last night announced he was resigning from the Senate because of personal reasons.
A Federal Police spokesman says officers have been interviewing several people during the investigation, but can't confirm the nature of the allegations involving Senator Woods.
Senator Woods, the Parliamentary Secretary for Health, has been in politics for nearly ten years.
PROSPECTS FOR INTEREST RATES CUT FALLING
Foreign exchange dealers say comments overnight in Switzerland by Finance Minister, John Fahey, make an early cut in official interest rates less likely.
Mr Fahey is being seen as playing down the prospect of an interest rate cut until it beocme clearer where wages are heading.
The Australian dollar strengthened by about a quarter of a cent overnight and foreign exchange dealers say that was prompted by Mr Fahey's remarks.
The Reserve Bank, holding its monthly board meeting today, has already expressed unease about the ACTU's safety net wage claim.
But industry wants the bank to go ahead with another interest rate cut.
The ANZ Bank has cut the interest rate on its basic variable rate home loan to six-point-9-5 percent, ahead of today's Reserve Bank meeting.
CHARLEVILLE SEEKS COMMONWEALTH HELP
An airflift of emergency supplies for the flood-ravaged Queensland town of Charleville is expected to be made later today.
The State Disaster Coordination Centre has asked for tents, stretchers, cooking equipment and staff, to assist the 250 residents who've been forced to leave their homes.
The residents are camped at the local high school and more evacuations are expected with the flood expected to peak early tonight.
Jack Vintner from the Coordination centre says the supplies will be flown from Brisbane, most likely on a Defence Force aircraft.
Road and rail links to Charleville are cut by flooding.
NATIVE TITLE TALKS TO CONTINUE TODAY
The Prime Minister will continue discussions on native title today, meeting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission representatives.
Mr Howard has already heard from State and Territory leaders, the National Farmers Federation and the Minerals Council of Australia.
Most States and the Farmers Federation are calling for Commonwealth legislation to extinguish native title rights on pastoral leases.
The Minerals Council doesn't believe that is the best option ... and ATSIC is strongly opposed to it.
Today's meeting with ATSIC is the first of two Mr Howard will be holding with Aboriginal leaders this week.
Mr Howard is also expected to outline Cabinet's proposals for a people's convention and vote on an Australian Republic at today's Coalition party meeting - the first one for the year.
CLAIMS AGREEMENT WILL LEAD TO JOB LOSES
The Federal Opposition says the first regional forest agreement will lead to jobs being lost because it doesn't encourage companies to invest in the local industry.
The East Gippsland regional forest agreement was signed by the Prime Minister and Victorian Premier yesterday.
There will be ten more such agreements across Australia.
Mr Howard says they will create jobs.
But Labor Resoures Spokesman, Neil O'Keefe, says the Federal Government has scrapped the incentive for companies to invest in Australia by allowing increased woodchip exports.
BELL'S SOLICITOR SAYS EXTRADITION EXPECTED
A solicitor representing alleged paedophile Philip Bell says it looks certain that his client will be extradited from South Africa to Australia to stand trial.
The admission came ahead of extradition proceedings which begin in the South African town of Humansdorp today.
Australian authorities are seeking Philip Bell's extradition to face 215 warrants relating to incidents involving underage boys.
Philip Bell has repeatedly claimed he is being persecuted over his lifestyle.
He has compared himself to Oscar Wilde, the nineteenth century Irish poet who was jailed for sodomy.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
